utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino along with Morgan Ortagus, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is "The Five." Fireworks at a high-stakes Oval Office meeting, President Trump and top Democrats Nancy Pelosi and Chuck Schumer clashing over border wall funding and avoiding a partial government shutdown in a heated face-off. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: And we have the easy one, the wall. That will be the one that will be the easiest of all. What do you think, Chuck? Maybe not?

utterances.speaker: SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER, D-N.Y.
utterances.utterance: It's called funding the government, Mr. President.

utterances.speaker: REP. NANCY PELOSI, D-CALIF.
utterances.utterance: You have the White House. You have the Senate. You have the House of Representatives. The fact is you do not have the votes in the House.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Nancy, I do. And we need border security. Nancy. Nancy. We need border security. It's very simple.

utterances.speaker: PELOSI
utterances.utterance: Of course, we do.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: When you look at these numbers of the effectiveness of our border security, when you look at the job that we're doing --

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.utterance: You just said it is effective.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Can I tell you something?

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.utterance: Yeah, you've just said it's effective.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Without a wall -- the last time, Chuck, you shut it down.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.utterance: No, no, no.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: And then you --

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.utterance: Twenty times. Twenty times.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: I don't want to do what you did.

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.utterance: Twenty times you were called for. I will shut down the government if I don't get my wall. None of us have said --

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Do you want to know something?

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.utterance: You've said it.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: OK, you want to put that in mind --

utterances.speaker: SCHUMER
utterances.utterance: You've said it.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: I'll take it. I am proud to shutdown the government for border security, Chuck. I will take the mantle. I will be the one to shut it down. I'm not going to blame you for it. The last time you shut it down, it didn't work. I will take the mantle of shutting down. And I'm going to shut it down for border security.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Democrats pouncing on the president, saying he'd be proud to shutdown the government over the border wall, but he's refusing to back down.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: I don't mind having the issue of border security on my side. If we have to close down the country over border security, I'd actually like that in terms of an issue. I mean, Chuck's problem is that, you know, when the -- when we last closed down, that was his idea. And honestly, he got killed. And so, he doesn't want to own it and I said you know what, rather than us debating who's owning it, I'll take it. I'll take it. If we close down the country, I will take it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK. So, Jesse, the meeting was mostly show no matter what, right --

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: That was all substance, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But, interesting, both sides feel like it could not have gone better for them.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, yeah, I guess if you're Democrat, you say Trump now has taken full responsibility for the Trump shutdown. And if you're Trump, you look at that video and you think I just manhandled these two people on live television and they look like complete buffoons. If you just look at the body language there, he was cutting them off. He was holding pieces of paper. Nancy, Nancy, Nancy. Chuck sitting there like a weakling. Nancy's getting interrupted the whole time. It was an extraordinary physical performance. At the end of the day, though, if you take -- no, I mean, look, on a debate stage, he did the same thing with Hillary. But these are two weaker people and he, you know, basically tag teamed both of them until they looked like blithering idiots. At the end of the day, though, he said I'm shutting this time for border security and I don't care if I take the heat. This is the last chance he's ever going to have to get the wall funding. It's either do-or-die. He's not going to get it in the next two years, and he may not get it in the next six. He has to go to the mattress on this. He has to own the issue. And if he doesn't get it, his supporters are going to show up in the general and say you know what? You had four years to build a wall and we didn't bring it together, what that's about?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: To that point, Greg, there was a NPR Marist poll today --

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Oh, I love it when you bring those up.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There was a chart.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A chart even.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Tell me more about this said chart. Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: When they asked Republicans should he compromise on the wall funding in order to avoid a shutdown, 65 percent of the Republican said do not compromise.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, there you go.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He's got that on his side. But then, of course, there was other parts of the poll that support the Democrats.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Can you just pull up that picture again of the group -- of the group discussing this? You know, we're missing the biggest story here which is Pence who has been cryogenically frozen. Yes, he was actually -- you know, they talk about -- they should have a body language expert do that to Pence right now because there's absolutely nobody there. It's just pure animatronic --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, that's exactly what I would do because I'm going, you know what, staying out of this --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: it's not the Pence shutdown.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I'm not involved. It's like -- I don't hang out with women who aren't my wife. I'm not getting involved. I'm staying out of trouble. But you know what the thing is, this encapsulates two things. One, why we hate tribal team sport politics because, believe it or not, there is a solution in front of them. You do this. I'll do that. We'll deal with DACA. You deal with the wall. There's a solution there, but they can't do it because even if they agree with what Trump is doing, they can't do it because it's Trump. They would agree -- that border security is important, but they can't admit it because then it would be Trump. And the challenge here is for Trump is that he's always choosing the long-term benefit that creates short-term public relations nightmares. This makes him look mean. The shutdown makes him look mean. But the long term win is enhanced border security, which is like national security, like law and order. He always take the long-term vision, but he gets, you know, reamed over this stuff.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Actually, Juan, one of the things Pelosi said to the president is that you have majorities in the House and the Senate until, you know, next month. You have the presidency. You pass the $5 billion. You get it done. And apparently, today, now, there's talk on the Hill that the House Republicans might actually just try to pass that. And I thought, well, why didn't they just do that before?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I think that's what Nancy Pelosi was saying to him. And then he was coming back and saying we don't have the votes in the Senate where they need 60 --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- Dana. So he was missing the point totally that he could, in fact, establish the baseline from which negotiations take place by having a vote among the Republican majority in the House. But I think it indicates that, you know, White House legislative office doesn't necessarily think they have the votes in the House right now, and that became apparent, I think, you know, the president encouraged the hard-liners and the freedom caucus, basically, today, to say unless it's got my wall, 100 percent, the $5 billion, don't go along with it. This is -- and as you point out in that NPR poll. Apparently, a majority of the Trump party people say that's the case. I must say the rest of the poll was overwhelming in terms of American saying, hey, you know what --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But if everyone -- right, but if everyone, Morgan, was posturing today -- this is the first meeting. It's the first one. I don't think all of them are going to be on television because you don't negotiate all your good stuff, you know, in front of the cameras. Maybe they will. I don't know. We'll see. What do you think -- where do you think it goes from here?

utterances.speaker: MORGAN ORTAGUS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Well, I think the big winner today was Schumer's press secretary. I was a press secretary before, not as high- profile as you, but Schumer kept going over and over again the same points, trying to make the point that it was the Trump shutdown. And when he finally got the president to say, he had this like -- on his face, like he was so happy that he got it out there. But I actually love this press conference. And I think a lot of Americans did. And the reason one is because it was -- it was the thing that people liked about Bernie and about Trump, no matter what party you came from, it's this ultimate disrupting politics. You know, instead of everyone getting in front of the press conference, in front of the press, and pretending like they all get along and like each other, they all just sort of threw it out there. It was like WWE. It was nasty. It was disruptive. But I think that's actually good for politics. I think that's what our founders intended. They didn't intend for everyone to play nice --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The founders wanted a wall. I think that was in the Federalist - -

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Federalist 41.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They've all said lock her up, but they didn't know what they meant.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And I must say if it was WWE or let's say a boxing match and you were scoring, the idea, as you've said, that he says, this -- yeah, I want a shutdown. I own it. I mean, nobody does that. Nobody --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's why he won.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because he doesn't think shutting down the government is gonna cost that much pain to regular people. The Democrats and the media become hysterical when there's a shutdown because they have to make it look like the government is so important to everyone's life when it really isn't. Also, Juan, one more thing, $5 billion in a budget that's what? Almost $4 trillion? It's nothing. It's symbolic. And that is what this is about.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It seems to me that when he -- not only says it's going to be a Trump shutdown, but then admits Democrats want border security and have voted for border security, which is what he did, again he undoes his talking points, Jesse. And when he talks about, oh, well, you know, people with disease are coming through, terrorists are coming through, all of it proven wrong, and yet he's sitting there spouting. People are like --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Homeland security has verified those things --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, they're not --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't know what you're talking about.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: State Department and Homeland Security said no evidence that any terrorists have come across that southern border. And the drugs --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There have been terrorist related people that have crossed the southern border. And Tijuana had says there are diseases down there with the caravan. I'm not demonizing it, Juan. That's just the fact.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I tell you what, we're not spreading disease. We're spreading falsehoods.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Google, people --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The drugs that you often cite. And, again, he says drugs are coming through that southern border. And everybody says, no, in fact, most drugs come through legal ports of entry.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You would know, Juan, because you sound like you're high right now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But this always comes out of the argue. Bottomline, process versus chaos. And so, he sits there and he comes off as the mean dad. We're going to have this wall and I'm going to shut down -- that's how a dad acts. They're the kids and they're not taking the medicine. It always comes down to this. And last but not least, Chuck Schumer reminds me of a vintage penguin from the original Batman. Total Burgess Meredith. Just the way he looks.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Totally,

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Actually, it's a compliment.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Josh Dawsey of the Washington Post reported that after the meeting, the public meeting, that apparently President Trump told them that in the new NAFTA, Mexico will play for the wall. It could still happen.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, listen, the markets need calming today. They're pretty volatile after this announcement, especially with the China terrorist. But it actually sort of goes together. I mean, I think this president has shown that he's willing to take political hits, right? He's willing to take the terrified to China. Take the I.P. fight to China and others. And so, I can see why Democrats are happy that he took it today. But, he's willing to take on the hard stuff.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Schumer said he had a temper tantrum. I think that's what it looked like.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. We're going to move on. Time has announced its 2018 person of the year. We'll tell you who got the spot and where President Trump finished, ahead on The Five.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: More Mueller probe developments this week in the Manafort, Cohen, and Flynn cases. Today, Paul Manafort's legal team responding to Mueller's accusation that he lied to investigators. Plus, lawyers for Michael Flynn are expected to make sentencing recommendations. We could learn more about his cooperation with the special counsel as a result. Meanwhile, Alan Dershowitz, the lawyer, says there's a double standard at play when it comes to new developments in the Russian investigation.

utterances.speaker: ALAN DERSHOWITZ, HARVARD LAW PROFESSOR EMERITUS
utterances.utterance: Let's assume when Bill Clinton was running for president, Paula Jones came up to him and said unless you pay me $130,000, I will reveal our affair. I guarantee you the New York Times, NBC, MSNBC, would be railing against any prosecutor who dared to suggest that this was a violation of campaign finance law. We need a single standard. If you wouldn't go after Bill Clinton, don't go after Donald Trump. If you're going after Donald --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, I mean, I guess the obvious thing is that -- it would have been during a campaign for campaign finance validation. But, Jesse, what we're experiencing today is Paul Manafort, apparently, seeking a delay in terms of trying to appeal for -- to the judge that he not get a longer sentence and contradicts the idea that Mueller is saying he lied.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm going to get to Manafort in a second. Permission to make an analogy, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I thought the one yesterday was fantastic.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The Botox analogy?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. I thought that's fantastic.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I like to make another analogy. OK. So, the congressional slush fund that they use from taxpayers to pay off these sexual misconduct settlements, millions of dollars over decades. Hundreds of people. Are those ever reported as campaign expenditures? Do those ever get filed with the FEC? That's just about getting reelected. That's about silencing people so they can win reelection. It's the exact same thing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Is it in the middle of a campaign?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Airtight. It's always in the middle of a campaign --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I just want to say, I just feel like this entire Mueller prosecution is being done with malice. Look at what they're doing to people. Flynn, highly decorated guy, bankrupted him over -- something that people don't really think was a lie. Manafort, greedy guy but they're treating him like whitey bulger kicking down the doors at the dead of night putting him in solitary confinement. Papadopoulos, the guy's life is ruined. No one even knows who he is. And then, Carter Page who they initially spied on, he can't get another job. If you look at what happened to Scooter Libby and the other one during the Bush years, he went to prison and he wasn't even the one that revealed the identity of the CIA agent. Susan McDougal in the Clinton situation, she went to prison and she didn't even want to cooperate with Ken Starr. They're just ruining people's lives because they're criminalizing conduct that happens all the time in Washington, D.C. And then you look back and you think where's the collusion?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Does it hurt you to go that far afield --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I feel no pain, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- to try to confuse the audience.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think the audience hears me much clearly than they hear you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't think so. I think people aren't as foolish as you might think. Morgan, let me just ask you, Michael Flynn, apparently, gave substantial assistance so he's not in Manafort situation. What can Manafort do to prove to the judge that, in fact, he didn't lie to the prosecutor?

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Well, I'm sort of sad that you called on me first because I know how much Greg likes this topic. It's his favorite thing to talk about on Fox News.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: So, it is very interesting how Mueller has treated Flynn versus how he's treated Manafort. You know, clearly -- and I think a lot of it is the fact that Flynn, you know, led the DIA and was a decorated general for so long, went into -- what Mueller said ultimately. I mean, all of this stuff is really difficult because it is all speculative. But Flynn has been the one that I've had my eye on the entire time because he was so intimately involved in the top of the campaign for a long time. And so, if he's cooperating that is -- I think if there were any collusion which, so far, I agree with Jesse, we haven't seen that, but if there were any collusion, I think Flynn would be the one to know about it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But, in fact, again, it would appear that Mueller is treating Flynn with some regard, some respect given his military service.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's not the only reason.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, go ahead.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Manafort has been a criminal for a long time.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The sentencing memo about Flynn -- about three quarters of it is redacted, right? Nobody knows really why. The reason is because they asked for no jail time for Flynn is because he cooperated and was very helpful. We don't know how he was helpful. And I think that when he files his sentencing memo, he'll just say thank you for recommending no jail time. Thank you and then walk out. Why would he say anything else?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right. But, at the moment, didn't you say he offered substantial assistance, right?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's the key that that comes from --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But you're saying that he was being lenient on -- Mueller that was being lenient on him because he was a decorated war veteran.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no. I think in addition to that. I think what he said in that memo --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: In addition to.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. This guy is a decorated war hero. And, of course, held very important positions in our government. Greg, you've been dying to --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I want to respond to you saying accusing poor Jesse of going far afield. Going far afield is talking about Manafort and Cohen over and over again because no one can find the collusion. Look, I'm still waiting for the crimes that are committed by Donald Trump to somehow blossom from this orgy of accusations about other stuff. By the way, I did watch the Clinton affair, which is the ANE. And it makes me full dersh now. I'm a full Dershowitz because you realize these investigations are basically -- they're like computational A.I. Once they start, they gobble up everything. Ken Starr had a lot of convictions, including Susan McDougal. She went to jail because she refused to cooperate. And I watched that -- I didn't know -- in the '90s, I was, you know, I working in health magazine. I wasn't -- didn't know much about this.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So did Judy Miller.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You realize that all this is, is a self-perpetuating machine that once you start it, it's up to itself to end. And you've just heard all these people --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Prison machine.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's a prison machine. And you look at like Flynn who served his country just get swallowed up. And I've said it on Friday or Thursday, the last time we had a show that I was on. You don't want to be in government.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You don't want to be in government because if you win, you've got a target. If you lose, you lose. It's better to lose.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But don't switch the topic.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Susan McDougal and Clinton. We're talking about Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, I guess you can't get history. I thought you were historian, Juan. Did you write about history? Forget history. Once they forget history, OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, I didn't say that. I'm all for it. But I just think --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I also defended a Democrat, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You did. All right --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Try that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Who was that, McDougal? Anyway, up next, is Time Magazine taking a shot at President Trump with its 2018 person of the year? Big news, stay tuned to The Five.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Time Magazine revealing its 2018 person of the year. The magazine announcing the guardians and the war on truth as this year's winner. The four covers featuring killed and imprisoned journalists including slain Washington Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi, and the staff of the Capital Gazette Newspaper in Maryland. Time says these journalists helped expose the, quote, manipulation and the abuse of truth around the world. Meanwhile, President Trump was runner-up and special counsel Robert Mueller came in third. I'm going to go to the magazine guy, Greg Gutfeld. What do you make of this pick?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, I think, this is their way of doing Trump without doing Trump.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And giving it to themselves.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah. And the thing is it's -- we know that this is no testament to the state of media in America. Trump has reinvigorated media after eight years of them being Obama toast, as I like to say. He's actually made the media better. The media can't see it because they're incited. Every time Trump says fake news is the enemy of the people, they only hear news -- or they think it's the media. They deliberately eliminate that part of the equation because they feel guilty. I would have actually have made it about the intellectual leaders that we talk about who are challenging the anti-speech mob, the biggest threat really in speeches on campus and now it's moving into companies. People like Claire Leman, Jordan Peterson, Dave Ruben, Joe Rogan, Sam Harris, Gad Saad, Debra Soap, Bret Weinstein, Eric Weinstein, those are the people --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Are you having your own award show?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I'm having -- they're the new warrior group. They're the people that are coming out and talking about controversial ideas and going against their own peer groups. That takes serious stones.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Dana, you've seen these things before. Is Time Magazine person of the year -- is this a thing of the past? Does anybody care anymore?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, all I know is we do this segment every single year --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Everybody does.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because it's fun.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I have a feeling it's not irrelevant yet. It gives you something to talk about and we can reflect. I think that their choice is perfectly good. I don't think they'll ever give it to President Trump again.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They gave it to him in 2016, and I don't think -- I mean, if he wins reelection, maybe they will do it again.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But I think that they'll probably never do it again. And you look at some of the other people that were on the list. I mean, I'm sorry, but Dr. Christine Blasey Ford, the accuser in the Kavanaugh hearings, to me I'm like, really? That's going to be one of your picks? I thought that was pretty --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think because Trump is so overwhelming that they couldn't find anybody else.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And then Putin is on the list? I mean, it doesn't mean -- it's somebody who's been influential. Putin --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. I mean, it's a stretch to not give it to Donald Trump every single year.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. In infinite, right, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think we should stop this show. Trump forever, you know. But the reality is, I think, that there really is a problem. I mean, what the editor said was if you look -- not only Vladimir Putin, but you look at what's going on with the Saudis, right? And then you can bring it back to silicon valley, they're there so many lies, so much spin right now that people are -- you know, to phrase it, really took off this year, gas lighting, that people are confused. People don't know what is truth, and people are being told things with the intent to undermine --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Fake news, finally you agree.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, they should have given it to Hannity. He's the one exposing all these lies and propaganda.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I will stay away from that one.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. But I will say that -- I think the quote of the year is Giuliani's quote, truth is in truth, right? It's a lot like Kellyanne Conway saying alternative facts.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That was like an existential comment.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right, right, right. But when there is so much assault on just simple facts and reporting, something's going on and I'm glad the Times said something here is wrong. And, you know what? People like Khashoggi murdered for telling the truth. They deserve to be on it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. How about you?

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Believe it or not, I'm actually inciting with Juan on this. I think that there's two different perspectives. There's the American media perspective where I think we see Acosta and others that showboat. And I think that makes all of us really irritated --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm surprised they didn't give it to Acosta.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: I know. The American media. But if you look at the international media, the Washington Post reported in October that 43 journalists have been killed worldwide. There's been at least 153 journalists killed in Syria. So I know a lot of the audience has been in the military and served overseas. I've served overseas in a civilian. And in these war zones, when I was in Iraq in 2007, when I've been in Afghanistan, there's really brave people, reporters that are in these war zones telling the story, reporting. And so for me, I just want to step away from the American media, where I think there's a ton of faults --

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, HOST
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: -- that we document all the time on this show. And look at the brave international reporters like Marie Colvin. The movie "A Private War" is out, talking about how she was killed in Syria doing a job that nobody wanted.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So if you use that -- OK, that's fair enough. If you use death, death in a career, as -- as the criteria, we should go down the list of what is the most dangerous jobs. What are the most dangerous jobs? Is it journalists? I don't know. I'm asking.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, HOST
utterances.utterance: Police officers are pretty lethal -- under fire.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think we have some -- people in the military. Although it's gotten better. If you look at, like, accidents in -- with, like, machinery, it's in pretty incredible how many people die on the job.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The war on coal.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I mean --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Dangerous out there. Why are you laughing, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know. That threw me off. I was actually being serious.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So was I. I know coal miners. It's a very dangerous job .

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK, there you go. All right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Were you on the short list for the TIME magazine.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.utterance: Very short.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Why does it have to be short? Why does it have to be short?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's a phrase. It's just a phrase.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what? I assume the worst of every phrase now. I'm learning that you meant something by that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK, we'll talk about some more phrases in the break. All right. Are the Oscars going host-less? Some potential big changes following the Kevin Hart controversy. Up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Since Kevin Hart bailed from the Oscars, the awards show is desperately seeking new options, including going without a host at all. Now, think about that. The Oscars looked around at all the possibilities in their own inoffensive, morally-pure industry, and they decided, "You know what? It's just not worth it. We're all jerks, clowns, sinners, bigots and pigs. And of course, we're petrified of the mob," meaning they're actually human. And just as every human has a skill or talent, we all have a past or a life, one worth more than a tweet. But for some, a simple dignified apology will never be enough. The moral majority is now the mobbing morality, and forgiveness is viewed as an accessory to evil.

utterances.speaker: And the Oscars is responding the way everyone does now
utterances.utterance: to be so gun shy about the social media fallout that they just give up and give in. No one wants to share the risk. So nothing too edgy, and humans are just that in the face of unforgiving hordes. So after decades of filling that hosting position, humans need not apply. So who then? How about Deep Blue, the chess playing computer? It's cold, faceless and never told a joke offensive or otherwise ever, much like Seth Meyers. Or how about a drone, something that can drop a crude joke from on high, then completely disappear? Like Michelle Wolf. But whoever they pick will be hosting the show from under a rock or under the Rock. Unless, of course, they find someone with guts who's not afraid of courting scandal. Who could that be?

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.utterance: PHOTO OF DONALD TRUMP

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's my choice. But you know --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'll take the risk. Isn't that what he said?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I'll take the risk. But people don't want to take the risk. So it's like even the -- the Oscars, to me, is like any business. They're like, "You know, we don't want any trouble." You know? And they step away, and then they just kind of --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Talk about picking up your ball and going home.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Basically, that would mean that we wouldn't have to do a show about the Oscars to talk about movies we haven't watched.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right, that's true. Whenever we do a segment, we pretend that we actually watched -- no, we don't pretend. We don't pretend at all.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I also remember it was just, like, two weeks ago that Joy Behar was frustrated about that Country Music Awards, because they didn't make it political.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So you can't have said anything offensive.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's the --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You can say something political, as long as it's offensive to half the country.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly. That's the point I should've put in the monologue. Dammit!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I thought it was a very good monologue, one of your best, actually.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think you should probably take more days off to refresh yourself. Because coming off with monologues day after day after day, that's why you get the thin ones once in a while. But this one was good. This one was really good. I don't really have much to add. I will say this. People in film and art in Hollywood, these are supposed to be the creative, edgy --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- people with expression and not afraid to take risks. And they're the most uptight squares ever. They've ruined the Oscars. They did the same thing with the White House Correspondents' Dinner. It got too edgy for them. They blew it. And then they -- now there's a historian up there instead of a comedian.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Now that --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Political correctness is literally ruining comedy. Has anybody ever said that before?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think I just coined that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think you did. Morgan, why don't they --

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: I'm glad you remembered my name.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Did you notice he looked down?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I looked down. I have a problem with names -- I have a problem with names on live television.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: I'm on your show a lot.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know. That's right. That's right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Even worse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And I do have a shrine in my office.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: But I was on your show when the guy was like -- who was it? Remember? The lady -- he was like, "The lady at the other end of the camera."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. He had (UNINTELLIGIBLE)

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But you are also on on "Special Report," too.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Thanks for bringing that up.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, why not create a host? Pixar, hologram, the whole damn thing.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Well, there you go. I don't care about the Oscars. What I do care about, I want the Oscars to continue, because I love the fashion segment at the beginning. I watch the Oscars, because I'm so girly. Like, I love seeing the women coming out in gallons. I love the earrings and the fashion and the hair.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Why does it have to be girls?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, Greg likes watching the women come out, too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: No, I'm saying that I like watching the girls. Guy fashion is boring.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So -- you're so cis-normative. Why can't the men wear the dresses?

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: I don't know what that cis-normative is.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Oh, now you don't even know what that is.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Right. I'm done. Bye.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Gee whiz.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, HOST
utterances.utterance: No, stay. Stay.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Guess you can't host the Oscars.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Juan likes me.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I like you. You stick around.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what bugs me? Is we're witnessing the death of forgiveness for mistakes. Like, I know you guys did this segment yesterday about the Heisman Trophy winner, about a tweet when he was 14.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And it's like Kevin Hart, you know, he already apologized, and then had to apologize again. Where are the comedians? Shouldn't they be - -

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think Kevin Hart -- by the way, you said Kevin Hart bailed. I don't think Kevin Hart bailed on them. I think they were very reluctant to defend Kevin Hart.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's true.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So he said he's not going to feed the social media frenzy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But then he apologized again.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, he apologized. But you know, it wasn't a real apology in the sense -- I think it was sincere in the sense that he said he evolved.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And lots of people have evolved on this question --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- of homosexuality --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Of course.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- in public life.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Obama.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right. So what's the big deal here, once he said that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But the way that the Twitter social media universe works is it's unending, and it is unforgiving.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I will say, in response to your idea that we give Max Headroom the job, I think that it would be interesting --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Would that be the highest rated, though, ever?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Of course it would be. That's what I say, it would be. But you'd have to have, like, a computer graphics. And I suspect, to play to Morgan's theme, have the person dressed in unusual ways and say edgy things. Right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: We could go back. We could go back to, like, Redd Foxx and Mitch -- who is that great comedian? Mitch --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Hedberg? He's dead.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Mitch Hedberg, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They're both -- holograms.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's what I said. That's right. You know how they -- in fact, we were at the Reagan Library the other day, our friend Bret Baier and Chris Wallace and I. And they have now Reagan as a hologram. Like you know how Michael Jackson is in Vegas?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They've got Reagan as a hologram.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: What about Howard Stern?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That would be fun. No, but that's the exact opposite.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He'd never survive.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He can't do it.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: If you listen to his radio show lately -- I listen to it all the time.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I listened to it today.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I thought you were so girly a minute to go.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: I am. I like the fashion.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, no, no.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Did you see the line-up --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Listening to Howard Stern go after women?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We're now talking about "The Howard Stern Show."

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: You can be feminine and still like Howard Stern.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, I'm sure, but I'm just thinking boy, you know, for a woman to hear this kind of talk.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: She's got a wide range of interests.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: She does.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Trust me, I've heard sailors say a lot worse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think we need to bring forgiveness back. We have to make forgiveness hip.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: My point was, like, three weeks ago we had Dan Crenshaw on "Saturday Night Live" --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- and everyone said that's the model for how we should handle it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And then everybody forgot.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I have something to raise.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Sure.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. NASA -- you remember them -- is on a new mission to prove to a basketball superstar that the moon landing actually happened. It didn't. We know. Total sham. Right, Lou?

This is -- I think this is -- people -- it's funny but it's sad, because it's going to be harder to convince anybody of anything with photographic evidence, because you can -- technology now, you can -- I can place Jesse in some kind of surveillance camera footage and falsely accuse him of a heinous crime, because that's where we are in technology.

But you go, "You know what? Maybe those were actors, and maybe that was done on a soundstage." "Capricorn"? What is it called, "Capricorn One"? is that the movie with O.J. Simpson?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Do we have the sound now? Yes. You want to play it?

utterances.speaker: STEPH CURRY, NBA STAR

utterances.speaker: VINCE CARTER, RADIO HOST
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: KENT BAZENMORE, RADIO HOST
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: CURRY
utterances.utterance: They're going to come get us. I don't think so, either. Sorry, I don't want to start any conspiracies.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS

utterances.utterance: I believe that we went to the moon. I'm a patriot. I'm an American patriot.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Nine-eleven was an inside job.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.utterance: Well, as you know, it's Christmas time in the city and time for a FOX News party. Big-time. Take a look at these pictures from last night. They had -- or I should say we had an indoor snow machine and enough food to feed Rudolph and the rest of the reindeer. You know it's fun to see people you work with. You can see Steve Doocy, Brian Kilmeade, Ainsley Earhardt there. Thanks to FOX and to all the cooks, the waiters, the technicians who made our holiday party a reason to blow the roof off last night. It was fun.

utterances.utterance: Wow. FOX called it a holiday party?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Nice one.

Vacations for the Gold Star families were coordinated by the Gary Sinise Foundation's Snowball Express program. According to a press release, the foundation will host a five-day experience for almost -- well, 1,722 children of the fallen and their surviving parent or guardian. It's a great thing every year, and people in Nashville really stepped up.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
